Andam is a Postdoctoral Fellow for the International Service for National Agricultural Research. Contact him by e-mail.[CR-LF][CR-LF]Andam joined IFPRI in January 2008. His most recent research, evaluating the effectiveness of land use policies and their socioeconomic effects, was awarded the Joseph Fisher Dissertation Fellowship from Resources for the Future in 2007 as well as a Georgia State University Dissertation Grant in 2005. Most recently, he led a research project funded by the Global Environment Facility (GEF) to evaluate GEF investments in the forest sector in Costa Rica, using data and methods from his PhD dissertation. His previous work experience includes three internships with the World Bank, where he contributed to monitoring and evaluating projects in the Middle East and North Africa Region. Kwaw has a bachelor's degree (first class honors) in civil engineering from the Kwame Nkrumah University of Science and Technology, Ghana; a master's degree in civil and environmental engineering from the University of Vermont; a master's degree in economics from Georgia State University; and a doctorate in public policy earned jointly from Georgia State University and Georgia Institute of Technology.

Contact Profile: Birol is a Research Fellow in the Markets, Trade and Institutions division. Her current research focuses on avian influenza and food and water safety.[CR-LF][CR-LF]She joined the markets, trade and institutions division of IFPRI in July 2007, as a member of the food and water safety team. From 2004 to 2007 she was a postdoctoral research fellow at the University of Cambridge. While at Cambridge, she conducted research on the development and application of economic methodology, to inform sustainable policies for environmental conservation and natural resources management in European Union and developing countries. From 2000 to 2004, she was a research fellow of the Center for Social and Economic Research on the Global Environment, University College London. She also worked as a consultant for IFPRI’s environment and production technology division from 2004 to 2005 and for Bioversity International from 2001 to 2004. She taught graduate and undergraduate level courses at the universities of Cambridge, London and Reading. She has a doctorate in economics with a concentration in agricultural and resource economics; an MPhil in economics with a concentration in development economics and econometrics, and an master's degree in environmental and resource economics, all from University College London.

Cook is a Senior Business Editor for the National Desk who covers Business and Finance. He focuses primarily on U.S. and international economic policy, corporate productivity, technology, workplace benefits and competitiveness in American business. He wants business stories that are timely and that interest a broad-based, savvy, business-minded audience. Try to tie your pitch into current economic trends. He does not want what he calls mass market pitches. He prefers that your guest or expert have some broadcast experience. He'll usually conduct a pre-interview to see if they are comfortable on the air. He'll only use them if they sound good. He does not want pitches on books on management issues. [CR-LF][CR-LF]Cook says that although they don't cover individual small businesses very often, they will feature a story on a small business if there's a larger issue involved. For instance, they featured a small start-up company interested in building a community on the web. They sell t-shirts designed by artists. As members, artists get cash prizes if their design is selected by the company. The story's angle of a company wanting to build a community of artists via the web caught Cook's attention. He prefers to be contacted via e-mail. Weekday afternoons between 12pm and 5pm are the best time to reach him.[CR-LF][CR-LF]Career:[CR-LF]Present - National Public Radio, Senior Business Editor, National Desk[CR-LF]1991 - National Public Radio, Supervising Senior Editor[CR-LF]1982 - NPR, Associate Producer, Acquisitions Unit[CR-LF]KCUR-FM (Kansas City), Reporter[CR-LF][CR-LF]Education:[CR-LF]Johns Hopkins School of Advanced International Studies, M.A. international public policy

Davies is the Publisher of Chemical & Engineering News. Contact him via the main e-mail.[CR-LF][CR-LF]The focus is more on the scientific equipment side than the drug development. He is interested in recent research advances in biotechnology, research and technology trends, major industry mergers and acquisitions and breaking industry news.  [CR-LF][CR-LF]They are interested in information technology products that advance the drug research and development process. They conduct interviews with industry leaders, scientists, IT specialists and marketing managers from companies whose product is making breakthroughs possible. They want to hear from people who are closely involved with the product. [CR-LF][CR-LF]They are also interested in clinical trial results of new drugs and biotech products. The publication covers all types of news, but Davies says, "The more prominent the company is, the more likely we are to cover their news. If we haven't heard of the company, we most likely won't cover the hiring of their new vice president."  [CR-LF][CR-LF]News releases should be sent to the executive editor via e-mail. Davies says, "Sometimes press releases are too long, but if they were too short we would probably complain there wasn't enough information." [CR-LF][CR-LF]Davies is not an appropriate PR contact.[CR-LF][CR-LF]Davies, the founding editor of Nature Genetics, has worked in scientific publishing since 1990. He has served on the editorial staff of Nature and as the science editor at the Howard Hughes Medical Institute. Davies has written for numerous publications including The Times, New Scientist, THES, Newton, Lingua Franca and Prospect. He is the author of the books The $1,000 Genome (Free Press, 2011) and Cracking the Genome: Inside the Race to Unlock Human DNA (Free Press, 2001). He has also served as the editor in chief of Cell Press.  He earned his bachelor's degree in biochemistry from Oxford University and he has a doctorate in genetics from the University of London.

Mathews is an Education Columnist for The Washington (D.C.) Post. He focuses on admissions, AP and International Baccalaureate classes, inner-city schools and KIPP schools. He only wants to receive very newsworthy items. Any pitch must include hard data, such as survey results or other quantifiable measures in order to be considered for a story.[CR-LF][CR-LF]"If you don't have data showing that what you are doing has had a marked effect on student improvement, don't bother to contact me," he says. He likes stories about specific actions that teachers or schools are taking to improve or track student performance; new or unique testing methods; and teacher recruitment and retention. His weekly column often focuses on higher education, particularly college admissions and student perspectives on it or related matters. [CR-LF][CR-LF]He's not hot on technology and will not cover products unless there is data proving they enhance education. He is also interested in programs that challenge average and below-average kids. He admits he is "very picky" about the press materials he will look at. Contact Subjects: Agriculture & Farming; Economy/Economic Issues; Natural Resources; Water Power
Contact Profile: Msangi is a Research Fellow covering Environment and Production Technology. He co-leads IFPRI's research theme 1, which focuses on the major socioeconomic and bio-physical drivers affecting agricultural production and trade, and their impacts on nutrition, poverty and the environment. While a great deal of his current research activity focuses on the economic and environmental impacts of biofuels, he has a broader research background in natural resource management, especially that of surface and groundwater management policy. He also has interests in quantitative dynamic economics, empirical agricultural production analysis for environmental policy and the application of dynamic game theory to the study of user behavior in natural resource settings. Contact him by e-mail.[CR-LF][CR-LF]Msangi joined the staff in August 2004 as a post-doctoral research fellow from UC Davis where he was a graduate student. He has done extensive research on ground and surface and groundwater allocation policy in the state of California, as well as core methodological work on stochastic dynamic programming applications and the calibration of agricultural production models for environmental policy analysis. His thesis research included the management of rapidly declining groundwater resources in Northern China, and the application of dynamic game theory to the study of user behavior in water markets. While at Davis his research also included the bionomics of resistance to antibiotic use in infected populations, and the application of information-theoretic methods to the estimation of agricultural production and natural resource models. He has also studied International Development Policy at the Food Policy Research Institute at Stanford University, where he also received an undergraduate degree in chemical engineering.

Contact Subjects: Associations and Non-Profits; Philanthropy; Volunteer Organizations
Contact Profile: Palmer is the Editor and covers all aspects of Philanthropy, including Grants, Fundraising, Management of an Organization, Personnel Moves, Technology and Foundation/Charity News for Chronicle of Philanthropy. When pitching a story, remember that the bottom line for them is how many of their readers are going to be affected. Send them News and Trends in the Philanthropy Spectrum. They are also interested in articles that offer Tips to their readers about Running a Successful Philanthropic Organization. They're more interested in quality than quantity; they won't report on every development at an organization, but when they do report about something, they tend to take a more in-depth look than most general publications. Make sure to know what makes a story unique or an organization different from other nonprofits, because the staff will ask. It also helps to be forthcoming with information; they are a bit wary of organizations that keep certain aspects of their operations secret. When they cover Gifts and Grants, they are usually for at least $1 million and $10,000, respectively. Yet, they will cover smaller ones if there is something different about them or if they go to a unique place. The staff prefers contact via e-mail, and a follow-up e-mail is OK if they do not respond. Do NOT call unless it's absolutely necessary. Contact the assistant managing editor with media inquiries. Also keep in mind that stories with the following topics should be e-mailed to these addresses: Gift Announcements, gifts@philanthropy.com; Grants, grants.editor@philanthropy.com; Conference, Workshop and Seminar Announcements, datebook@philanthropy.com; and Personnel News, people@philanthropy.com.[CR-LF][CR-LF]Career:[CR-LF]1988 - Present - The Chronicle of Philanthropy, Editor[CR-LF]1984 - The Chronicle of Higher Education, Senior Editor[CR-LF][CR-LF]Publications:[CR-LF]2004 - Challenges for Philanthropy and Nonprofits: The Courage to Change[CR-LF][CR-LF]Education:[CR-LF]1982 - Brown University, B.A. International Relations

Robertson is a Research Fellow in the Environment and Production Technology division. His work is concerned with harnessing GIS and parallelized computation to help deal with research problems of a spatial nature and those which are prohibitively difficult to tackle using conventional computational resources. The interaction between the land surface, water and human activity usually fall into these categories.[CR-LF][CR-LF]Robertson joined IFPRI in 2008. Prior to that he completed environmental and water related post-docs at the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign in the civil and environmental engineering and agricultural and consumer economics departments. His doctoral research revolved around empirically modeling land use decisions using very large datasets to estimate discrete choice models. Prior to that, he earned a double major in mathematics education and physics from Andrews University in Michigan.

Contact Profile: Rosegrant is a Division Director for the Environment and Production Technology Division. He currently directs research on climate change, water resources, sustainable land management, genetic resources and biotechnology and agriculture and energy. His region of expertise is Asia. Contact him by e-mail.[CR-LF][CR-LF]Rosegrant was named director in 2003 and had been a senior research fellow in EPTD since 1993. He has also developed the International Model for Policy Analysis of Agricultural Commodities and Trade, which has become a standard for projecting global and regional food demand, supply, trade and prices, as well as IMPACT-WATER, which integrates a detailed water supply and demand model with the food model. He has extensive experience in research and policy analysis in agriculture and economic development, with an emphasis on critical water issues as they impact world food security, rural livelihoods and environmental sustainability. He is the author or editor of six books and over 100 refereed papers in agricultural economics, water resources and food policy analysis. He holds a doctorate in public policy from the University of Michigan.

Taylor is a Blogger who discusses Arts and Cultural News and Trends. He also examines the administrative and business aspects of the arts industry.[CR-LF][CR-LF]He is director of the Bolz Center for Arts Administration, a graduate teaching and research center in the University of Wisconsin-Madison School of Business. An author, lecturer, and researcher on a broad range of arts management issues, Taylor specializes in business model development for cultural initiatives and the impact of communications technology on the arts. As a communications and management consultant, he has worked with the International Society for the Performing Arts, American Ballet Theatre, StreamingCulture, the Center for Arts and Culture, and the League of Historic American Theatres, among others. He helped develop the pro forma and operating plan for Madison, WI $100-million downtown arts district, and led the business model development team for a proposed Digital Dance Library initiative. Taylor received his master’s in Arts Administration from the University of Wisconsin-Madison. Valmonte-Santos is a Research Analyst in the Environment and Production Technology Division. Her current work focuses on natural resource management with emphasis on food security in developing countries, participatory approaches to community based fisheries management and gender, threats and opportunities of climate change, and to some extent biosafety and biotechnology in selected Asian countries. Contact her by e-mail.[CR-LF][CR-LF]Valmonte-Santos joined the staff in December 2003 under a joint appointment with the Communications Division and the Environment and Production Technology Division. Prior to joining IFPRI, she worked as an assistant scientist in Policy Research and Impact Assessment Program, WorldFish Center, Malaysia. While with WorldFish, her work included resource and ecological assessment (ecosystem and water quality) of selected rivers, lakes and bays in the Philippines, community management and assessment of aquatic resources in the Mekong River Basin (Vietnam, Thailand, Lao PDR and Cambodia) in relation to gender, food and nutritional security of the fishing and farming population, socioeconomic assessment of capture fisheries resources in South and Southeast Asia and identifying strategies and options to increase and sustain fisheries and aquaculture production to benefit poor households in Asia. She also conducted a series of training workshops on water quality assessment for university lecturers, government and non-government officials in the Philippines and agroecosystem training for university students, lecturers and government officials in Vietnam. She received her master's degree in environmental studies from the University of the Philippines Los Baños, Laguna, Philippines.
